ScriptedActionInfo.comment: The sub scripts must complete before acharacter can execute a command
so this top level script must wait for the command completion
wait for fast results to be displayed
wait for result to be submitted

VoiceMap.Text: I'm Marcus Washington. I've been a resident at MedStar for four years this May. The way we do things around here is that I'm responsible for examining the patient, but you have to tell me what to examine. I can help you out with any procedures you might want. Also, I have extensive experience with FAST exams. You're going to have to make all the final decisions, though.
Don't forget Henry. He's the latest model SimMan mannequin. One of our techs brought him over the other day.
We've found that clear open communication works best during a resuscitation. A good place to start would be vitals. Why don't you ask David to put Henry on the vitals monitor to see how he's doing.
You can use the viewer to look at FAST images, CTs or Xrays.
If you forget a result, remember that you can review any images you've ordered from here.

This is probably a good spot to bring up team communication. We are helping you out here, because you are new to the unit. Everyone on the team is highly skilled, but they are counting on your direction as the leader. If someone is too busy, we'll let you know and perform your orders in sequence. If you lose track, our Scribe Nurse records all your orders on the Recent Orders clipboard.
If you feel like you've lost control of what's happening, you can say Stop Everything, and we'll quit working on existing orders, and wait for new ones.

While its good practice to address who you are talking to, our Trauma team is responsive. You can give the order and as long as we're qualified, we'll get it done. If we don't know what your asking for, we'll tell you.
If you want to get up close and personal with Henry, don't be shy. Come closer to the bed.
Let's go over patient exams. Let's say you wanted to check Henry's trachea for deviation. Just ask and I'll report my findings.
The patient's trachea is midline, Doctor. Excellent work!
Would you like more practice with orders or do you think your ready for your first real case?
Henry doesn't talk much, but if you have a question for a patient during a code, just ask them.
I told you he was shy. If your patient doesn't respond to verbal questioning, ask me to perform a glasgow coma scale or a neuro exam for you. Speaking of exams...
Hi... You must be our new Doc. Did you get lost on your way in here? Don't worry about it, this place is a maze.
Marcus, this is our new Trauma Team Leader. Why don't you guys introduce yourselves.

Oh! I didn't introduce myself. I'm David Keller, I've been an ER Nurse here at MedStar for three years now. On a code, you can count on me to handle fluids, meds, and give you vitals when you ask. Just give me the orders.
What do you say we ease into your first shift with Henry. A little sim practice, goes a long way...
Hey Doc, come over to this side of the bed. I'll show you how some of our equipment works.
This is the main vitals monitor. You can see it from most places in the room, but there's also one over the patient's head if you need it.
Around here, we refer to imaging as 'adjuncts'. Go ahead and call for an Xray to get started, and I'll see how soon our tech can get here.
Nice work! Let's go over a few more things.
Hey Doc, Henry's looking a little dry. What do you say we give him some fluids?
You can ask for saline, crystalloid, as well as blood products. We've also got pressure bags and a level 1 infuser if you need it.
Alright, let's get Henry some point nine normal saline.
Some things like saline are right in the room. When you ask for other things like blood products or scans or consults, it will take a little while.
When you have done everything you can for your patient you have a few options. You can Admit or Discharge your patient, as well as send them to interventional radiology or the operating room.

Usually you will need to specify an injury when moving a patient to the OR or IR. We've also experienced wait times depending on the needs of other patients, so don't be surprised if room isn't available right away. Ask the Scribe Nurse and she can handle the calls for you.
You're doing great! I'll call the rest of the team in.
By the end of the week it will feel like your second home. We're going to be in Bay 2 today.
Let's get started. We like to show the new people how things work using the trauma mannequin.
The Xray Tech is on their way.
What area would you like to scan, Doctor?
